image.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: Indian-origin activist among three women charged for staging protest in Palestinian's support in Singapore
item.description: Three women, including an Indian-origin activist, faced charges for organizing a procession supporting the Palestinian cause without a permit in a prohibited area. They carried umbrellas symbolizing solidarity and delivered letters to the Prime Minister's office.

item.title: Texas woman with her 16-month-old son denied boarding after misgendering flight attendant
item.description: Jenna Longoria, a women's health expert from Texas, was refused boarding on a United Airlines flight from San Francisco after unintentionally misgendering a flight attendant twice while boarding. Despite seeking assistance for her crying son, Longoria and her family were barred from the flight, allegedly for excess carry-on items—a claim she disputes. United Airlines cited concerns over comments made, including those about transgender issues, prompting backlash and leaving Longoria seeking clarification and resolution following the incident.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Watch: Bolivian general gets arrested on live TV after failed coup attempt
item.description: On Wednesday, Bolivia experienced a swift and dramatic coup attempt led by General Juan José Zúñiga, who claimed to be acting to "restore democracy." Armored vehicles rammed the government palace doors, prompting President Luis Arce to call it a coup attempt. Within hours, Arce named a new army commander who ordered the troops to stand down. The rebellion ended after three hours, with soldiers and military vehicles retreating. Hundreds of Arce's supporters celebrated outside the palace.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Absolutely f*****g hates him': Will Prince William forgive his brother Prince Harry ? What experts say
item.description: Prince William's strong stance against Prince Harry's actions and firm control over the royal family indicate a slim chance of reconciliation between the brothers in the near future. Michael Cole has claimed that Prince William, is "not going to forgive" Prince Harry because there is "too much bad blood," between the royal brothers.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Attorney who beat Trump twice in court starts boutique firm
item.description: Roberta Kaplan, the prominent trial lawyer known for representing New York writer E. Jean Carroll in her lawsuits against Donald Trump, is leaving Kaplan Hecker & Fink, the firm she founded seven years ago. Kaplan announced on Wednesday that she is starting a new boutique firm, Kaplan Martin, with partner Tim Martin and a trio of close friends. The new firm will specialize in civil litigation, internal corporate investigations, and strategic advisory. Kaplan cited the unexpected growth of Kaplan Hecker & Fink and her desire to shift away from white-collar matters as reasons for the change.

item.title: Nepal Rains: Landslides, floods, and lightning kill 14
item.description: Nepal faces a grim toll as recent monsoon activities claim lives across various regions. Landslides, floods, and lightning have led to multiple fatalities, highlighting the nation's susceptibility to natural disasters. With La Nina conditions predicted to influence rainfall patterns, proactive measures are essential to mitigate the impact on vulnerable communities.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Heroic act turns fatal: New Jersey man killed by lightning while warning others of storm
item.description: Patrick Dispoto, 59, was struck by lightning and killed while warning beachgoers of an approaching storm at Seaside Park Beach, New Jersey. Despite his girlfriend Ruth Fussell's pleas to stay safe, Dispoto returned to the beach to alert children. Emergency responders' efforts to revive him were unsuccessful. Following the incident, Seaside Park installed a $50,000 Strike Guard Lightning Detection System. Fussell remembered Dispoto as a selfless person who always helped others, calling his final act "ultimate heroism."
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Fired after complaining about poor repair work on some Boeing 787 jets', claims whistleblower
item.description: Richard Cuevas raised safety concerns about Boeing's 787 Dreamliner construction, leading to investigations by various authorities. He has filed complaints with two US agencies, claiming he faced retaliation after raising concerns about potential manufacturing issues on the Boeing 787 Dreamliner. The FAA is actively looking into the multiple safety reports received this year.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'You can’t suppress it forever': Prince Harry opens up about losing mother Diana at 12
item.description: ​​Having lost his mother, Diana, Princess of Wales, at the age of 12, Prince Harry offered his perspective on coping with loss. The video, shot in May and released ahead of Armed Forces Day, aims to highlight the support needs of bereaved military children in the UK. Harry spoke frankly about the misconceptions children can have after losing a loved one.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Russia starts secret trial of US scribe for spying
US jails Honduran ex-president for 45 years on drug charges
item.description: A court in New York on Wednesday sentenced former Honduran president Juan Orlando Hernandez to 45 years in prison after he was convicted of trafficking hundreds of tons of cocaine into the United States. He was convicted in March of having facilitated the smuggling of hundreds of tons of cocaine -- mainly from Colombia and Venezuela -- to the United States via Honduras since 2004, starting long before he became president.

item.title: Italy busts gang smuggling in Chinese via luxury cars
item.description: Italian police said Wednesday they have busted a Chinese trafficking network which used luxury cars to smuggle Chinese migrants into Italy, before confiscating their passports and treating them like slaves. The smugglers had the migrants pose as "unsuspecting Asian citizens, well-dressed, with little luggage, travelling in powerful and expensive cars, driven by Chinese citizens who had lived in Italy for years and spoke Italian", police said in a statement.
